So what?

Alien, the Thing and The Exorcist are massively influential, available, and discussed horror films, so many people will encounter them first or early in their horror viewing lives, are often on TV, etc. So, either nostalgia, or beyond nostalgia looking at horror as a whole, those three will often be in best of favourite lists, and deservedly so.

Similar with Blair Witch, especially for people at the time of release.

Texas Chainsaw is a solid pick for slashers, and any one who likes the subgenre will probably pick on of the big three. It would be my pick, too, for its strangeness and beauty, and constant atmosphere.

28 Days is prime example of rage-zombies and fast paced survival horror, also nostalgia pick for many.

Signalman and Mungo have similar themes, anon seems to have an unfortunate preference for FF. Noroi fits into that.

So you have some of the best and strongest examples of horror, with a bias towards FF, with some of the best examples in (mostly aweful) subgenre.

com:
Miller's Crossing is so fucking good, the way the Coens are able to maintain tension and weave as they see fit, leaving Tom's fate and his constant gambling with his plans in the air up until the last possible second is something, and to that so early in their career? These guys are just an example of how studying the greats and putting your own stamp on it goes along way to making a great film and they're certainly the giants of American cinema.

I also marvel at the fact how they took that motorbreath delivery that's seen as a staple of noir/mobster films and made it their own with their own brand of wry humor they're known as. I've been ignoring their opus for years now only having seen Lebowski, Fargo and NCFOM, but recently I've been going through their filmography and I am really impressed by the sheer quality of their output, they overshadow their duds no question about it. And those slick references to Barton Fink are neat, I love shit like that!

Anyway, /tv/, what's the rumpus on Miller's Crossing, you chewing over it or you a potato eater?
